name: Remember Watergate? Quiz | Campaigns & Elections | 10 Questions

questions.text: At the time of the Watergate break-in, the apparent front-runner for the democratic candidacy was who?
The head of the Committee for the Re-election of the President - appropriately called 'CREEP' - was:
questions.explanation:
John Mitchell.

	It was Attorney General Mitchell.

questions.text: This individual warned Nixon that there was 'a cancer on the Presidency'.
questions.explanation:
John Dean.

	Dean was the man.

questions.text: The disclosure that Nixon kept tapes was made by whom?
questions.explanation:
Alexander Butterfield.

	Butterfield's claim to fame.

questions.text: Nixon's loyal secretary offered a bizarre explanation for the disappearance of 18 and a half minutes of material on one of the tapes. Her name was:
questions.explanation:
Rose Mary Woods.

	She claimed to have "accidentally" erased part of one of the tapes, but to do so would have required her to press buttons simultaneously that were several feet apart. Not very convincing.

questions.text: Which of the following individuals was NOT a player in the Watergate scandal?
questions.explanation:
Oliver North.

	North was a major player in the Iran-Contra affair, which took place during the Reagan presidency.

questions.text: Watergate forced Nixon to step down from office in August of which year?
Nixon's democratic opponent in the Watergate-tainted election was whom?
questions.explanation:
George McGovern.

	McGovern got wiped out in the election.

questions.text: Nixon was able to select Gerald Ford to be his successor because his previous Vice-President had stepped down previously for what reason?
questions.explanation:
Criminal misconduct.

	Spiro Agnew was forced out due to criminal problems.

questions.text: Woodward and Bernstein broke the story for the Washington Post. That newspaper was run by whom?
questions.explanation:
Ben Bradlee.

	The three wrong choices are associated with the N.Y. Times.
